body:
Does anyone know if there is some reason I would get `AssertionError: PyTypeTest on non extension type`, like what sort of coding error (on my end) would cause that? Strangely enough it goes away when I run cythonize again, but on first cythonize on the first `setup.py install` I always see it, and I'm not sure if it's my fault or not

Edit: here's the full compiler trace:

```
Compiler crash traceback from this point on:
  File "Cython/Compiler/Visitor.py", line 180, in Cython.Compiler.Visitor.TreeVisitor._visit
  File "/home/jonas/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/ParseTreeTransforms.py", line 2211, in visit_FuncDefNode
    node.body = node.body.analyse_expressions(node.local_scope)
  File "/home/jonas/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py", line 436, in analyse_expressions
    for stat in self.stats]
  File "/home/jonas/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py", line 436, in <listcomp>
    for stat in self.stats]
  File "/home/jonas/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py", line 6672, in analyse_expressions
    self.item = self.item.coerce_to(self.target.type, env)
  File "/home/jonas/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/ExprNodes.py", line 949, in coerce_to
    src = PyTypeTestNode(src, dst_type, env)
  File "/home/jonas/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/ExprNodes.py", line 12965, in __init__
    assert dst_type.is_extension_type or dst_type.is_builtin_type, "PyTypeTest on non extension type"
AssertionError: PyTypeTest on non extension type
```

comment_data.body: The mailing list seems a better place to ask questions like this.
(Note that this is impossible to answer without seeing the code that you are compiling.)
I don't have a minimal code example sadly, and it happens only sporadically...

btw if anyone else finds this through google, try use a seperate process for each Cythonize call. (e.g. through `subprocess`) for me, that made it go away. seems to have been some issue of internal state carried over that shouldn't have been between the compilations
Is the (non-minimal) code available somewhere?

@scoder 
I now got this error in a different project of mine as well which is public, the exact code line where Cython crashes is this one: 

https://github.com/JonasT/nettools/blob/a8b9236f985d468e49953f818dad3dcb1bbe2b77/nettools/cssparse.pyx#L101

The crash only happened in one of my virtualenvs so far set up by [python-for-android](https://github.com/kivy/python-for-android) and I haven't seen it in my regular manual install yet, so I haven't had a chance to poke around this. I'm however very certain python-for-android is completely unrelated (since I've seen the crash in the original comment outside of it) but it's just that it only happens sporadically so it is quite random to get it to show. And it seems to happen only **if other files previously have been compiled / cythonized** (so it seems to be some left over state issue)

Just to make it a bit easier for you to investigate:

https://github.com/JonasT/nettools/archive/a8b9236f985d468e49953f818dad3dcb1bbe2b77.zip

This is the exact package version that broke things at the lines 22 & 101 &.... (see Cython's detailed error mesage above) in `nettools/cssparse.pyx`.

It is installable as pip target as well, like this: `pip install --user -U <url>`, or you can extract it & enter the folder and run `pip install --user -U .` which should do almost the same thing (minus some third party lib constraints) as the crashing install command did.

So, according to the stack trace, it's not the `__init__` line that crashes here but the following list comprehension. Somehow, I think, the type of the loop variable `i` might get inferred and lead to a type check.

I tried building your code several times (with the latest Cython master) and it never crashed for me, even though it was translating the two other `.pyx` files before `cssparse.pyx`. I improved the assertion error message a little to report the unexpected type, so if you want to retry it on your side, you can use the latest master ~~(you might need to set language_level=2)~~ and see if you get a better error message out of it if it crashes for you.
You can also try renaming `i` in that list comp and see if that makes a difference.

I am primarily interested in helping you fix Cython instead of searching workarounds *if* that is also what is you are interested in. This is the new output/backtrace with the new assert:

If you want to do an experimental branch with even more debug info or whatever would help you, I'd be happy to install & run that one and have it print out whatever you need

A couple of things that I noticed in the stack trace:
```
      File "/tmp/easy_install-f0tg5i58/nettools-master/setup.py", line 110, in <module>
        # Work around https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2886:
```
That's not an executable code line, so something might have gone wrong with the source file between import and execution.

```
setuptools.sandbox.UnpickleableException
```
The fact that this runs in a "sandbox" feels suspicious. Could it be that Cython gets imported independantly into multiple "sandboxes" and something leaks between the different instances? That would explain an error like this. The type that it complains about here is a global singleton, but it seems to have been duplicated somehow, which makes a prior equality comparison fail and lets it run into this assertion. It's supposed to compare the type to itself in this case, but that evaluates to false, which suggests that there are two singletons instead of one. That can lead to arbitrarily wrong decisions in the compiler and generate quite different code in the end, even if it doesn't crash.

Did you always use setuptools when this happened, or does it also occur outside of pip/setuptools?

Some more info regarding the sandboxing: extension modules cannot be reloaded (or loaded multiple times) in CPython, so if Cython gets reimported, its compiled modules would remain in place but other modules (such as `Builtin.py`, which defines the singleton) get reloaded, which would then create a new singleton. One of Cython's extension modules, `FlowControl.py`, stores a module global reference to the singleton. This means that it could end up keeping the first reference to the singleton (because it is never reloaded), whereas the rest of the modules would use the freshly created instance of the sandbox.

I just pushed a change to master (6a6a8f4509e0b1987a91e570a6ca7fae0e9e1989) which probably isn't enough to work around this issue, but at least avoids the global reference to the singleton in `FlowControl.py`. I think we'll have to find out what setuptools uses for its sandboxing mechanism to see if there is anything we can do about it (or anything that can be improved in setuptools).

@scoder no I have indeed never seen this outside of setuptools! I have only ever seen it in setuptools and only if multiple things are installed/cythonized in a row, and it goes away if I run Cython with `subprocess` as an external clean process (which I've done in one of my `setup.py`s as a workaround attempt)

@jaraco sorry to ping you so out of the blue, but there seems to be a potential issue with the setuptools sandbox related to Cython & unintentionally kept around global state. Would you possibly have an idea what could be going on here? (I can also file a setuptools ticket if that is the better way to go ahead)

I haven't had time to investigate directly or even read the whole thread, but I have some information I think may help.

Here is how [setuptools creates a sandbox](https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/blob/4cd3da049027b6321a56ca4724c3a072d1c32cd1/setuptools/sandbox.py#L183-L195) and here's [where it does it](https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/blob/4cd3da049027b6321a56ca4724c3a072d1c32cd1/setuptools/sandbox.py#L230-L254).

As you can see, with the sandboxing, several things occur, including:
- Any exceptions caught are pickled inside the sandbox and restored outside the sandbox (see save_modules / ExceptionSaver). I don't remember why it does that, but if I had to guess based on my experience, it's because the modules that own that Exception might differ inside the sandbox, so saving it allows the exception to be meaningful in the outside context. This might explain how a type might not match expectation.
- modules are deleted and thus allowed to be re-imported, which may affect global state.

Another factor to consider is that the sandbox is only ever employed when `easy_install` is invoked, usually through `setup_requires`. It should be possible today to avoid the invocation of `easy_install` entirely by using `pip` and PEP 517/518 constructs. In fact, if pep517 is employed to invoke the build process, by design it runs each build in a subprocess, so that should bypass any issues with global state across builds. Since `easy_install` and `setup_requires` are (soft-) deprecated, it may be worth exploring if there's a way to invoke these builds that avoids that behavior altogether (rather than trying to solve it).

Another possible, though probably less likely, culprit is [the extension code](https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/blob/master/setuptools/extension.py) that interacts with Cython, and late to effectively detect the presence of Cython only after something like setup_requires has had a chance to run.

In summary, I suspect the sandbox code is having some bad interaction with Cython and my recommendation is to investigate if it's possible to avoid relying on setup_requires in the project or projects to bypass the issue.

Hope that helps.

@jaraco out of curiosity, does `install_requires` have the same issues? If yes, what's the replacement? I haven't actually seen one anywhere, since last time I checked `requirements.txt` wasn't automatically picked up when doing `pip install --user -U /path/to/package/source/` (unlike `install_requires`/`setup_requires` which are) such that a naive install attempt would fail which is a bit problematic for the end user

Edit: also, thanks a lot for your insightful response! :heart:

`install_requires` get translated into package metadata, so are honored both by pip and easy_install... So while `pip install /path/to/package/source` doesn't honor requirements.txt, it will honor the `install_requires` for that package and install those dependencies (unless you supply `--no-deps`). So no, it doesn't have the same issues.

ah nice, so `install_requires` is fine? Good to know. NowI'm wondering though, I may actually need to use `setup_requires` since I need the dependencies to be around for `build_ext` despite build isolation, not sure if that's usually the case? I'll experiment, maybe I can just ditch `setup_requires` - I added it because I globally imported a module from the deps in the `setup.py` but I don't do that anymore, I only locally import it inside the `build_ext` hook.

Not sure what to do with this ticket though, I mean I guess it's obvious it's not working right, but I can certainly not decide what side should possibly consider a fix or if it's even worth fixing

(if you're wondering why I need a dependency during `build_ext`, it's because I do cross-package `.pxd` `cimports` for an additional speed boost which only works if the dep is around during the cythonization (with its `.pxd` files that it installs into site-packages). I am making an app for android so for some hot code paths I really tried a lot of unusual things to eliminate unnecessary slowdown factors in the call chains :smile: )

Just as a small status update, indeed I could just move my `setup_requires` to `install_requires` and now everything works perfectly fine :+1: so at least for me personally this is solved by no longer using `setup_requires` for anything else other than `Cython` itself
